content: The Act is titled the "Genetically Engineered Food Right-to-Know Act" and its purpose and findings are outlined in Section 2. The "Genetically Engineered Food Right-to-Know Act" aims to establish a standard for labeling foods produced using genetic engineering, including fish, to inform consumers about the production process. Congress recognizes the material changes in genetically engineered food and the right of individuals to know if their food was produced using genetic engineering. The Food and Drug Administration requires labeling of over 3,000 ingredients, additives, and processes, while more than 60 countries have laws mandating labeling of genetically engineered food for various reasons. More than 60 countries, including the United Kingdom, European Union, South Korea, Japan, Brazil, Australia, India, China, and other key trading partners, have laws mandating disclosure of genetically engineered food on labels. Codex Alimentarius, the UN food standards organization, allows governments to decide on labeling genetically engineered foods. In 2011, Codex Alimentarius adopted a text allowing governments to decide on labeling genetically engineered foods, which can preserve economic value in exports and sensitive markets. SEC. 3.
